posts.content:
Hi, I'm looking to fit the headliner this weekend. Do I just fit as normal, then fit the overhead table holder later or leave it loose. Does anyone have and pics of the holder (or headlining in place?) How does the fix to the van? Does it sit on the lip?

Thanks

Jim

Fit headlining as normal.
Then upper luggage cards as per monkeys post
Rear table holder is then help up by screws into the cant rail along each side 2 or 3 each side? Plus one each side of each of the rear hinge covers. The ones at the back have black domed covers over them.
Do you have rear cupboards?
These are held to the rear table holder by one threaded bolt and by screws with two domed headed cups along the edge of the rear hatch.
If all has been fitted before then locating screw holes in interior will guide you where holes in wood line up with holes in metal.
I managed to strip mine out on my own and refit mine on my own..but need something to prop if all up while fitting it.
If need to drill holes..trial fit before headlining is put in and drill holes to hold up.
I had a problem that upper rear boards are repro and thicker than OG.
The rear cupboards are held with simple right angle brackets on the front lower corner
Still need to adjust mine to get these to work.
All is in but not quite right...
Will post pictures..

Really appreciate that. No, I don't have cupboards as it's a 13 window. So it should be a bit easier.

Thanks.

Jim

I do not intimately know the upper rear panels between the last row of windows on a 13 and the rear hatch BUT the issue I had was that I was fitting a thicker upper rear luggage trim panel..Plus I fitted OG VW cups and screws. This resulted in the unmolested rear table holder not fitting easily onto the cant rail, because it clashed with my cupped screws. I removed the cups because they were covered anyway...
If your is not trimmed and never fitted before I would trial fit and ensure that the wood does fit up to rail with a little room for the headlining fabric etc.
I will post pictures of fittings for overhead table.
It is very heavy when you try to keep up in the air and I was only aligning mine with existing holes.
Really a co-ordinated two person job..
I used some plastic boxes to rest it on in the centre so I could work on the outside to fit the screws.
Examine your holder to see where the OG holes were or if none replicate my positions.
Will post pics tonight..
G

author.location: Bridgnorth, Shropshire. I am a member :o)

posts.content:
I have just refitted my table holder after a bit of fettling and re-French polishing - and concur with Graham above - Devon fitted to their furniture to finished vans - so headliner all in place first.
On mine (67) there were two screws inside the rear cupboards each side and 2 right at the back by the hinges, on the table holder tails with black domed screw caps on.

I'd imagine on a 13w with no cupboards it would be devon screwcaps all along.

I managed to put mine back in on my own, but it was a struggle - I too used my coolbox on the rear bed to hold it relatively close - well enough to get a screw or two in anyway.

I struggled to find the proper domed black plastic caps - I used to have thousands when I worked in the Trade as dome headed numberplate fixings - but I was struggling to find a supplier these days - I kind forum member sent me a few in a jiffy about a year ago - now all used up on my refit - just enough!

author.location: Bridgnorth, Shropshire. I am a member :o)

posts.content:
Well what do you know after another search I have found some this time!

http://www.beal.org.uk/automotive/number-plate-screws/100-x-domed-number-plate-screws-black-/prod_5363.html

Really appreciate it. Sounds like fun!!

Just realised I don't have any hinge covers so I'll have to buy some. Do they go over or under the head lining? I look for some reference photos later

Thanks

Jim

author.location: Bridgnorth, Shropshire. I am a member :o)

posts.content: Re: Hinge covers - I took these off too for a light fettle - they had turned a rather horrible shade of brown(!) and were slowly turning to dust - gave them a quick once over and a spray up with a rattle can and refitted - Just about saved them - they were very brittle. But anyhoo they fit OVER the headlining with about 6 screws each - which seems like a lot for a small item! and when the table holder is in place you can't see any of the screws!

The hinge covers go over the headlining. There are holes in the metal work..
Make sure you know where they are... 5? Per hinge....
The screws are stubby galvanised cross head screws.
There are repro covers available from WCM....but the rear edge needs trimming because it interferes.
I bought some but did not fit them. My OG ones disinregrated and thrn I was given an OG one and found another and these fitted a treat..
Most of the cover is covered and only a small piece sticks through.
The repro ones are good but you will have to trim as do this as you try the rear table holder.
Also search for Claricks from Scotland...on eBay..They sell the dome head number plate screws and caps.

So....sign I am getting old...
Everything I do seems to take longer..but at last I have some photos...
I took the pictures of Catherine 1965 OG untouched interior rather than Peebles and these do confirm I have more work yet to do to get Peebles rear table holder to fit better..
I took pictures of rear table holder and rear cupboards each side.


Rear table holder and rear hinge cover gone brown and shows the number plate style screw holding the rear table holder and the black cover.






Rear cupboard










This picture is taken inside the passenger side rear cupboard and shows the cup and screw fixings on the side panel and attempts to show the two screws going upwards into the cant rail..
Can see one clearly and attempts to show the other.




Hope these help.
You have more windows...No rear cupboards and will have a shorter rear panel.
May still have ahem.. trouble getting it up .... against the cant rail.
With Peebles the side panels were thicker.
Really I need to take it all back out again and trim the edges..
As it is my rear cupboards are hung by a bolt on a nut on the top side and I need to elongate the hole to move the top out to the centre to hang properly.

G
